title: How safe are underwater tunnels? Has one ever failed? - Quora

response.answer_text: “It all depends” on what you mean by “fail”. The very first sub-aqua tunnel in the world was built by Brunel uner the Thames. Yes, he should have drit deeper, for yes, it did penetrate the river bed and flooded. So he dumped a whole lot more soil on top, pumped it out, and continued the drive. Thames Tunnel - Wikipedia One of the tunnels of the London Underground passing under the Thames was hit by a bomb during WW2, and flooded. But it was a dis-used stub-end, which had been blocked off. A tunnel does not have to be “under water” to flood. There is groundwayter everywhere, and this can flood a tunnel, see Anticipating the Unexpected and once there, look up Orange-Fish Irrigation Tunnel, South Africa : Flood, Shaft 2 South, 1969But I have not heard of a “finished” underwater tunnel, open to traffic, that has flooded. Te only likely cause would be an earthquake, with a sizeable shift
